q: What are the common symptoms of bronchiectasis?
a: The most common symptoms of bronchiectasis include a persistent cough that usually brings up phlegm (sputum) and shortness of breath.

q: When should I see a GP regarding bronchiectasis?
a: You should see a GP if you develop a persistent cough as it requires further investigation.

q: How are the lungs affected by bronchiectasis?
a: Bronchiectasis causes one or more of the bronchi to become abnormally widened, leading to a build-up of excess mucus in the airways and making them more vulnerable to infection.

q: Why does bronchiectasis happen?
a: Bronchiectasis can develop if the tissue and muscles surrounding the bronchi are damaged or destroyed. It can be caused by lung infections, immune system problems, or allergies, but in many cases, no obvious cause can be found.

q: Who is at risk of developing bronchiectasis?
a: Bronchiectasis can affect anyone at any age, but symptoms typically do not develop until middle age.

q: How is bronchiectasis treated?
a: Treatment for bronchiectasis focuses on relieving symptoms and preventing further damage. It may include exercises to clear mucus, medication to improve airflow, antibiotics for infections, and in rare cases, surgery.

q: What are the possible complications of bronchiectasis?
a: Complications of bronchiectasis are rare but can be serious, such as coughing up large amounts of blood, which may require emergency surgery.

q: What is the outlook for people with bronchiectasis?
a: The outlook for people with bronchiectasis varies depending on the underlying cause. Most people have normal life expectancy, but severe symptoms can be fatal if the lungs stop working properly.
